forecast.review:
Forecaster 2’s base-rate emphasis and the Arraez 2023 example are solid and relevant. I agree that six weeks is enough time for regression to pull a .400 start down, and that modern pitching/defense suppresses extreme averages. Minor caveat: citing defensive shifts is a bit outdated post-2023 rule changes, but the general “run environment + pitching quality” point still stands. Their 6% seems low given a current candidate is reportedly ≥.400 and will only need to hit roughly .400 over the next ~6 weeks to remain there.

Forecaster 3’s reasoning on regression is fine, but their factual premise (leader at .375, Freddie Freeman) conflicts with the research noting Aaron Judge ~.401 on May 20. That undercuts their calibration. If anything, having a current .400 hitter should push odds higher than their scenario. Their 15% is close to my prior, but the mis-specified starting point makes me discount their pathway.
forecast.rationale:
Key updates from deliberation: (1) I give more weight to historical base rates and the Arraez 2023 precedent of fading in late June (Forecaster 2). (2) I revisited the arithmetic for the remaining period: from May 20 to July 1, expect roughly 35–38 games and about 125–140 AB for Judge. If he’s ~68/170 (.400), to be ≥.400 on July 1 he needs ≈52 hits in 130 AB (~.400) over that span; his slight cushion at .401 barely changes this. (3) Using a binomial approximation, if Judge’s true BA over the window were ~.36 (near his xBA), the chance of ≥.400 over ~130 AB is on the order of 15–20%; if his true BA is closer to ~.33–.35 once BABIP regresses, that falls to ~5–13%. Given his .481 BABIP vs ~.344 career and xBA ~.362, a blended view of p ≈ .34–.36 feels reasonable, implying a low-teens chance he sustains ≥.400 to July 1. (4) Add only a small tail for any other hitter to reach/hold .400 by then.

Net: I trim my prior 14% slightly downward due to the longer AB window (~130 vs my earlier ~110) and the strong base-rate headwinds highlighted by Forecaster 2, while still recognizing Judge’s present .400 standing and elite contact quality justify nontrivial odds.
